root.pub-comments: WALS doesn’t distinguish between languages and dialects, so all lects are called languages, but where Ethnologue considers something a dialect, it has been given a dialect code, and there is a comment.
root.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 602-605. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue: dialect of Min Nan Chinese. In Ethnologue, it appears that both Taiwanese and Hokkien are alt names for the dialect Fujian.

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue classifies Taiwanese as an alternate name for Fuijan. Fuijan is a dialect belonging to the dialect group Xiamen, which is classifies under the language Chinese, Min Nan (nan) according to Ethnologue.
child.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 602-605. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911

child.pub-comments: WALS claims this to be a dialect of Chinese (Wu). Ethnologue classifies Chinese, Wu as a language below Chinese, that has at least 15 dialects itself.

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue: Kham is a subgroup that contains 4 children: Parbate, Western (kji); Kham, Sheshi (kip); Parbate, Eastern (kif); Kham, Gamale (kgj). WALS claims there to be 5 varieties of Kham, but lists none.

child.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 602-605. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue does not recognize this as either a language or a dialect. "Shigatse" is the second largest city in Tibet, People's Republic of China. Alternate names for the city include Rikaze, Xigazê, Shigatse, Shikatse, and Zhigatsey. The city was formerly known as Samdruptse. It is possible "Tibetan (Shigatse)" refers to the dialect identified by Ethnologue as Gtsang (Tsang, Lhasa) [bod-gts], but this is unlikely.
child.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 602-605. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911
